evidence.text:
Person A: Really? I’m glad. Our relationship was mostly physical. She was always about to go off somewhere else, that’s why our lovemaking had that sense of urgency. It was like having sex with a terrorist, it always felt like the last time.
Person B: She rates you pretty highly as a lover.
Person A: I’d like to know what rating you give me… They take their drinks and sit in the dining room, on a large couch that had a previous life, but it is still pretty and special.
Person B: Damian, I can’t believe you’re still flirting with me.
Person B: No. In that case, no. This is an absolute secret. She doesn’t even know I’ve told you.
Person A: Okay, but if there’s anything you need, just let me know. I worry about you.

Person B: Don't you go to galleries? You used to love that. When we were together we'd talk about the power of art. Are you interested in that at least?
Person B: Yes, I remember that…
Person A: I’m not nostalgic, but I miss the nights when we’d drink, take drugs and have sex, and all that didn’t distract us from what we really wanted to do…
Person A: I don’t know how much you drank but you always acted like you were as blitzed as the rest of us, but you were always an essential part of the party. That is, until you got bored and went off to discover Europe. Do you want us to talk about that?

Person B: But you were with me!
Person A: He doesn’t care… He insists that I’m implicated. He spoke to a friend of Martha’s, Stella Byrne, who had refused to help her…

Person B: I need to go back to the house. I still have to pack up Martha’s things.
Person B: Yes… Of course you can come… I’m headed there now… I’ll text you the address… See you soon.
